The attitude which Gentili took toward the different branches ol law and the method which he followed in establishing judicial principles are more clearly shown in the Advocatio than in any ol his other writings, and perhaps in that lact the primary im· portance ot this work lies. In the first place he broke away from ecclesiastical tradition. Most ol his predecessors, men like Covarruvias, Suarez, Molina and Soto, who were Catholic theo· logians, carried over into theirdiscussions of international law the principles ol the canon law and the method of a priori reasoning. Gentili was a jurist by profession3 his adherence to Protestantism released him from ecclesiastical preconceptions, and the bent oi his own mind seems to have led him to the practice ol examining concrete cases ol his own time and of drawing practical rules from them. He may therefore with propriety be called the founder of the modern historical school of intemational law.
